data: Methionine adenosyltransferase I/III (MAT I/III) deficiency, caused by mutations in the MAT1A gene, is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by persistent hypermethioninemia, usually detected by newborn mass screening. There is a wide range of clinical manifestations, from completely asymptomatic to neurological problems associated with brain demyelination

This patient might be sicker than suggested by clinical impression. Failure to treat a child with Methionine Adenosyltransferase I/III deficiency who is unable to take adequate calories by mouth can result in severe hypermethioninemia, lethargy, and coma
q4h, Also check 20 min after D10W bolus if given and PRN

PED ED Peripheral IV and IV Fluids (Module)

Start IV dextrose 10%-sodium chloride 0.9% (D10NS) at 1.5 times maintenance and reassess rate after 2 hours if:  - hypoglycemia, glucose less than 3.5 mmol/L  - in normoglycemia but not able to tolerate oral intake  - patient has diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, high fever, signs of encephalopathy  - ketones are high  - there is metabolic acidosis
